BE

 At the time of appointing Mr Gregg as Chief Executive Officer, the Board of Primary was made
aware of an ASIC investigation into the affairs of Leighton Holdings and of Mr Peter Gregg’s participation in that investigation relating to the time when he was CFO of Leighton Holdings.
 The Board of Primary has been updated on the status of the ASIC investigation by Mr Gregg, insofar
as the investigation involves Mr Gregg, and has been assured that Mr Gregg has fulfilled and continues to fulfil all of his obligations in respect of the investigation and also that, in his position with Leighton Holdings, Mr Gregg acted at all times in accordance with the law.
 The Board remains comfortable with the performance and conduct of Mr Gregg since he was appointed Chief Executive Officer of Primary.
 As there is an ongoing investigation in progress, it is not appropriate for us to comment further on the matters raised in the media articles.

BE

Elaine Prior of Citigroup also has thoughts.

BE

General thoughts, which I assume have been cleared by Citi's very expensive legal team.

11:16 am
BE

This month bribery and corruption allegations have made significant headlines. In mid-March, news reports related to Tabcorp and Cambodian bribery allegations, and the related resignation of the CEO of the Australian Securities Exchange, who was CEO of Tabcorp in 2010. Investigations may come under Australian and US jurisdictions.

BE

On 31 March, a major news story surfaced under the headline “Big Oil’s Bribe Factory”. This included widespread coverage in the Australian SMH and the Huffington Post, followed by ABC coverage. Reports allege that Unaoil paid bribes on behalf of western companies, and mentioned a wide range of international companies associated with the oil industry in the Middle East and elsewhere. Australian companies Leighton (now CIMIC) and WorleyParsons were mentioned. The media reports that US, UK and Australian authorities are now investigating the allegations. The media also reports that the ex-Leighton CFO, who is now CEO of Primary Healthcare, is under investigation.

BE

Any legal investigations may be protracted, and we cannot judge what the outcome might be. However, as we have seen with past allegations relating to Leighton Holdings (now CIMIC), and more recently in the Tabcorp / ASX case, the initial fallout may well relate to individual executives. As we have seen, individuals can leave their current positions. Even when departures do not occur, we imagine that people who may be involved in investigations are likely to be diverted from focusing productively on their current roles. Further executive fallout seems very likely, though it is inappropriate to speculate as to where this will play out.

Senate Inquiry?

Labor and independent senators reportedly intend to bring forward to April an Australian Senate inquiry into corporate bribery, which might require corporate executives to appear for questioning.

How Can Investors Judge?

A frustrated major superfund asked us: how can investors better predict these types of problems, when companies tend to give good answers when asked about their bribery and corruption policies and approach? We believe we helped to “lift the bar” in terms of the “basics” with our series of four reports in 2011 to 2014 assessing companies’ public information on how they are managing bribery and corruption risk (see “ASX Companies: Bribery & Corruption Risk - Analysis of the Approach of 89 Potentially “At Risk” Companies”, 16 December 2014). However, going beyond this may require taking a more qualitative and subjective view of management and board quality and governance, and it seems impossible to be sure what really goes on inside a company.

11:17 am
BE

And perhaps that's all we want to say there for the moment.

Not a lot to same on Home I guess

PM

Looks a done deal with Sainsbury

Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 164.80, down 1 (-0.60%), High: 166.00, Low: 162.90, Volume: 3.66m
BE

Yep, it's moving to a conclusion and there's not a lot to add.

11:19 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 271.70, down 4.6 (-1.66%), High: 274.10, Low: 269.60, Volume: 2.99m
BE

Bernstein incoming.

BE

Our view is that this deal is well constructed, enabling EPS accretion, debt reduction and avoids a class 1 transaction. Sainsbury's is paying a 'fair price' for Home Retail group, getting a non-food supply chain very cheaply, 1/3 cost Tesco paid for Tesco Direct.

From a business point of view, the concerns about "Argos being a troubled business set for sustained decline" remain fully valid and that will remain a risk factor hanging over the SBRY shares in the coming years. However SBRY argues that those losses would be more than offset by the sustained growth of the existing fast growing SBRY non-food business, and the fact that SBRY is a better owner of Argos as it can rapidly reduce the foot print of Argos through its own store locations.

11:20 am
BE

We believe the proposed offer for Sainsbury’s offers good shareholder value for Home Retail Group’s shareholders and believe that the deal should be accepted. On a standalone basis, we see ongoing challenges for Argos, in the form of rising minimum wages in the UK, continued price competition from the likes of Amazon in key categories, as well as excess overhead following the sale of Homebase. While a Sainsbury’s acquisition will not address all of these issues, the ability to reduce rent through store relocations to Sainsbury’s concessions as well as to reduce central costs should alleviate some of the cost pressures on the business.

BE

So in terms of the timeline, we get the prospectus .... sometime.

BE

Usually it'd be within 28 days but the Panel's given Sainsbury a waiver on that. Not sure why.

11:21 am
BE

Q3 closure expected. Drop-dead deadline of March 2017.

BE

Oh, and should mention it's being done by a scheme.

BE

Meaning 75% approval.

11:22 am
BE

Which closes off the possibility of someone doing a Premier Foods, I guess.

BE

Here's Clive Black at Shore.

BE

[T]aking the 31st March closing price of J. Sainsbury stock, the offer represents 143.7p or £1.2bn plus the aforementioned add-ons of 27.8p brings a total indicative value of 171.5p (£1.4bn), a combined premium of 74% to the HRG share price of the 4th January 2016; a substantial mark-up to our minds and within our initial expected price range for HRG in this process of 160-180p, which leaves us comfortable that Sainsbury’s has not moved into ‘over-pay’ territory, a condition set out to control its own ambitions in this whole process.

Sainsbury’s still expect the tractions to complete in calendar Q3 2016 and the scheme of arrangement procedure will bring some pace to the process. Whilst this is so, we watch with some trepidation to see what the UK Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) makes of this proposed acquisition; Lord knows how their minds work on April Fool’s Day. Sadly, in the real world that businesses have to operate in, rather than the parallel and largely unaccountable environment of the CMA, we harbour concerns that this deal could yet face timetable challenges from the regulator; we hope we are incorrect in this respect.

We see the HRG Board recommendation as good news for Sainsbury’s management and we remain neutral on Sainsbury’s stock. We believe that the group is fairly valued on fundamentals, noting potential upside, albeit some risks to mitigate with respect to HRG, whilst keeping an eye on the group’s underlying grocery performance in the UK. HOLD.

11:32 am

MainFirst, the German brokerage, argued the case for Royal Mail merging with PostNL in the second half of 2015, once regulatory reviews in the UK and the Netherlands were complete.

A tie-up between the companies could deliver as much as 70 per cent of valuation upside for both stocks, MainFirst said. Royal Mail would benefit from PostNL’s experience in building a state of the art parcel network while PostNL would repair its balance sheet and gain expansion in markets beyond Benelux, analyst Tobias Sittig said.
He said GLS, Royal Mail’s pan-European division, would be a good fit for PostNL’s parcels business. PostNL has nearly 70 per cent of the consumer market in Holland but has had to invest heavily to fend off competition from business-to-business operators, and generates no synergies with its standalone letters division.

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz44HuyKLux

BE

However!

11:33 am
BE

There are reasons to sell Royal Mail beyond the vaguest of vague suggestions that it might be in for PostNL.

BE

Namely, it still has workforce trouble.

BE

Union pay proposals put forward yesterday are rather expensive.

11:35 am
BE

Jefferies to summarise.

BE

Initial union proposals imply annual wage inflation of 3.7%, worse than our
2.8% assumption. Although proposals will likely be watered down, a 50bps
change to our wage inflation assumption changes EPS by 8% and our DCF
valuation by 15%. We remain relatively cautious ahead of what we think
will be relatively difficult labour negotiations, likely involving pension reform
discussions. The next catalyst will be the delayed Ofcom consultation document
late April.
Expensive union proposals. The Communications Worker Union (CWU) will aim for a
35 hour working week by FY20E in negotiations with Royal Mail (vs. 39 hours today), with
no reduction in pay, translating into 3.7% higher annual wage costs, including costs for
overtime. Our estimates assume stable wage inflation of 2.8% (vs. recent union-led pay
deals at 2.5%). Although initial proposals will likely be watered down, a 50bps change to
our wage inflation assumption changes EPS by 8% and our DCF value by 15%. We have
only fine-tuned EPS estimates for now, reflecting a better GLS performance and positive FX
factors.
Pension reform discussions. We remain cautious as labour negotiations will likely involve
pension reform discussions, with DB cash contributions expected to increase from 17%
today to 30%-40% of pensionable payroll by FY18/19E, compared to DC cash contributions
of 6%. CWU said it would launch a national campaign, potentially involving industrial
action, against any attempt to close the DB scheme, which doesn't bode well for a smooth
process. Given the complexity of the issues, there might be a short-term pay deal for 2016,
followed by ongoing discussions for the later years.

BE

Plus, we don't have regulatory certainty yet.

11:35 am
BE

Ofcom doc expected late next month.

BE

Jefferies again:

BE

Royal Mail shares have performed in line with the European postal sector over the last six
months and are trading at 7.2x FY17E adjusted EBIT, in line with the sector. Our unchanged
DCF-based 400p price target assumes the costs of the pension reform will more than
compensate the hidden value in the London development property. Key risk factors include
worsening e-substitution, increasing competition in parcels, labour and pension reform
discussions and regulatory uncertainty.

BE

BE

Strategy department now follows.

BE

Oilmageddon averted

11:46 am
BE

In February, we suggested three inter-connected negative feedback loops which if uninterrupted, risked fuelling a dangerous "significant and synchronised" global recession. We also suggested that higher oil prices and renewed efforts by central banks to re-build credibility were important in breaking these loops. Both have happened. Oilmageddon has been averted and the feedback loops have stalled.

BE

The ECB faced triple threats from persistent inflation under-shoot, tightening financial conditions and loss of credibility. This drew an enhanced policy response in the form of lower rates, attempts at both liquidity and credit easing and an asset purchase program expanded in size and breadth of target assets to include € IG corporate bonds from the end of 2Q16.

BE

We argued at the end of January that there was a case for a tactical rally in Value. Further support for Value comes from: 1) extreme negative correlations between Value and all other styles, 2) crowded positioning away from Value, 3) stabilising/rising oil prices, 4) big negative Euro Area CESI levels, 5) Draghi's policy implications for credit spreads, 6) break-down of negative feedback loops, 7) end of extreme low-flation.

11:47 am
BE

We continue to see de-equitisation & FCF strategies, secure yield, credit spread beta and oil beta/exposure (we remain Overweight Oil & Gas) as legitimate Value+ strategies, rather than seeking Value for value's sake, which is not a strategy which we would pursue given the multitude of risks across the global economy and financial markets. In this report we update our "cheap delivery" screens. AstraZeneca, Intesa, Daimler, Allianz and Danske feature on a P/E and earnings momentum basis. Intesa, Allianz, Statoil and Daimler feature on a DY and dividend momentum basis.

BE

We make a change in our European sector strategy in this report. Previously, we cut the sector to Underweight at the end of last year. Following a sharp de-rating, we cut our Underweight and moved back to Neutral. Health Care has fallen back to a 10% P/E relative premium to the market. It has been at these levels four times in the last 5 years and the sector's average relative return in the 12-months after hitting these levels has been +12%. US election/political risks, as well as certain stock specific risks in Europe, stop us from being more positive. Citi's European Health Care team has Buys on Roche (Citi Focus List), AstraZeneca, GSK and Novo Nordisk.

BE

So that's that.

On thjs Canadian mushroom deal

PM

Fyffes this morning, has announced the acquisition of Canadian mushroom producer,
Highline Produce. Total consideration paid was €98m for 100% of the equity. This represents
an EV/EBITDA of 8.1x (broadly in-line with Fyffes’ current valuation). Management estimates
that it will be c.13% EPS accretive in 2016 and net debt / EBITDA will be less than 2.5x.
Highline Produce is the largest mushroom operator in Canada and is fully integrated
operating from five different facilities (4 owned and 1 leased). It generates c. 65% of
revenues in Canada (35% in the US) and sell 75% of its produce to the retail channel. The
business has been growing at low to mid-single digit recently. The current management will
continue in their roles in the business.

11:50 am
PM

The acquisition brings Fyffes into a new category which is higher margin and fully
backward integrated. The Mushroom industry is similar to Fyffes’ categories
(bananas, pineapples and melons) as it is large scale volume production, with
logistical efficiency the key to strong profitability. We believe the market will react
positively to this diversification of Fyffes operations.

PM

Patrick Higgins there is a buyer

Note: Tanvir Sandhu is a cross-asset derivatives market strategist who writes for Bloomberg. The observations he makes are his own and are not intended as investment advice.

BE

And here's SocGen.

BE

In today’s employment situation report, we expect 249K net jobs to have been created in
March, as jobless claims data has reached levels similar to what we saw last fall. The
unemployment rate should tick down to 4.8% and average hourly earnings are set to rise by 0.3% (2.2% yoy). We also expect a big bounce in the ISM Manufacturing index to 53.2 in
March, from 49.5 in February. Total vehicle sales are likely to slow slightly to a seasonally
adjusted annual rate of 17.3 million in March. Overshadowed by the numerous reports on the day, we expect construction spending to rise by 0.3% mom in February and the final reading of UoM consumer sentiment to improve to 90.5 from the preliminary reading of 90 in March. Lastly, Cleveland Fed President Mester (voting) will top off the active day of data with remarks on the economic outlook and monetary policy.

11:57 am
BE

And, oh I dunno, Deutsche.

BE

Commentary for Friday: Despite a trend-like reading on March ADP employment (200k vs. 205k), which was released earlier in the week, we expect a below-consensus increase in March nonfarm payrolls. In turn, this could result in a slight uptick in the unemployment rate. Our forecast of below-trend employment is broadly consistent with our meager projection of 0.5% Q1 real GDP growth. Tepid output alongside strong job growth has resulted in unsustainably weak productivity, and the likely outcome is an eventual slowdown in labor market gains.
Another reason we are less sanguine on March employment is that we have noticed a recent tendency for the median consensus forecast for March to overestimate the initially-reported March payroll gain. In fact, the median forecast for March has over-predicted the initial nonfarm payroll figure in five out of the last six years. The range of misses has been large. For example, last year, analysts were expecting a 248k hiring gain in March, and the initial print was 126k. This was the largest miss during the aforementioned period. Forecasters also overestimated the initial March payroll figure by 3k in 2014, 97k in 2013, 90k in 2012 and 38k in 2010. Only in 2011 did the initial March payroll gain exceed the median consensus estimate, and this was by a modest 31k. Thus, over the past six years, forecasters have overestimated the initial March employment gain by an average of 53k.
To be sure, average hourly earnings (AHEs) and hours worked are equally important for income growth. Regarding the former, last month's decline in AHEs was unusual, and there is potential for payback in March. However, it would take slightly more than a 0.2% gain in AHEs to keep the year-over-year growth rate steady at 2.2%, which would still be well below the 2.6% post-recession peak, reached last December. With the unemployment rate near most estimates of full employment, excess slack in the labor market has largely been absorbed at this point in the cycle. Year-over-year nonfarm payroll growth peaked at 2.3% in February 2015 and has declined to 1.9% as of this February. Thus, wage inflation will be needed to support income growth.

BE

It may be quiet but we'll give you content somehow, damnit.

11:57 am
undefined
BE

Inchcape? Anyone care?

Inchcape PLC (INCH:LSE): Last: 691.32, down 32.18 (-4.45%), High: 714.50, Low: 689.50, Volume: 410.84k
11:58 am
BE

Berenberg reckons the market's turning.

BE

The market being car sales, which as we've discussed a lot seem to be the main benefit of the People's QE that is PPI settlements.

BE

Berenberg saying all three of Inchcape's markets looking fragile now, for different reasons.

12:00 pm
BE

Volkswagen (VW) exposure in the UK seeing difficulties: With the UK car
market growing by 6.3% yoy in 2015, the majority of UK car retailers
recorded expansion in EBIT margin as higher volume was driven through
their existing fixed cost base. However, Inchcape’s UK retail EBIT margin
declined by 30bp to 2.0% – its lowest level since 2008. We believe that this
is largely the result of its large exposure to VW in the UK – c20% of retail
franchises – which came under pressure in Q4 following the OEM’s
emission scandal. While Inchcape’s management declined to provide exact
figures on the impact of the scandal on its UK business, we believe that in
Q4 alone it could have amounted to a loss of cGBP3m to EBIT (c5% of FY15
UK profit). With VW sales in the UK down by 13.5% ytd, we believe
Inchcape’s UK business (20% 2016E EBIT) could be at risk if this trend
continues.

BE

Australian FX issues: The bulk of Inchcape’s Australian business (26% of
2016E EBIT) comes from the wholesale of Subaru vehicles to domestic
retailers. With Inchcape buying its vehicles in Japanese yen, the
deprecation of the Australian dollar presents a risk to margin. While the
company believes that it can share some of this pain with the dealer
network, we wait to see how much can be passed on. We forecast a GBP3m
contraction in Australian EBIT for 2016 – but this could arguably be more.

BE

Hong Kong disruption: Despite an expected GBP6m tailwind on FX
resulting from an appreciation in the HKD:GBP, we do not believe
Inchcape’s business in north Asia will grow at all in EBIT terms in 2016
given the major slowdown in consumer and business confidence there.
Recent data would suggest that Hong Kong car market volumes could fall
by almost 20% in H116. If this were the case, Inchcape’s expectations for
total industry volume (TIV) in Hong Kong to fall by 10% in 2016 could be
optimistic.

12:00 pm
BE

So there you go.
